 I said knowledge is good, but too much is bad. I realize now that I made a mistake. Sorry, guys. I should have said, too much of the wrong kind of knowledge is bad.
 I believe that any knowledge that leads us away from God is the wrong kind. Knowledge is power – I believe that; it cures diseases, finds alternate fuels, strengthens security, etc. However, if one tiny particle in nature can lead mankind to believe that God doesn’t exist, then that act is, IMO, the wrong type of knowledge. If that discovery enriches life, then it is good. I could go into the presence of the Tree of Knowledge of Good and Evil, but I would hijack the thread, which I admit, I’ve been guilty of before, so I’ll try to stick to the topic and the basics of it.
 Religion is to mankind is as a chain to a hound dog. Until the dog is released he cannot do what he was bred to do. Finding that this is the case requires knowledge (which is gained through study) and wisdom (which is a gift of God). The wrong kind of knowledge increases the strength of the “chain”, people “run to and fro” searching for freedom, but finding only other “chains” that might explain their bondage. They wrap themselves into these chains and become entangled. After that pride takes over and they dispel the things of God and drift away towards worldly things. This is where knowledge itself corrupts. From that point they only accept things that they see, feel, or hear…physically. Mankind dies and turns to dust.
 To show how my faith guides me and why I post as I do about knowledge I can only show you scripture, but I can’t make you understand it or accept it:
 2 Peter 1 verses 3 thru 7, According as His divine power hath given unto us all things that [pertain] unto life and godliness, through the knowledge of Him that hath called us to glory and virtue: Whereby are given unto us exceeding great and precious promises: that by these ye might be partakers of the Divine Nature, having escaped the corruption that is in the world through lust. And beside this, giving all diligence, add to your faith virtue; and to virtue knowledge; and to knowledge temperance; and to temperance patience; and to patience godliness; and to godliness brotherly kindness; and to brotherly kindness charity.
 
 You mentioned imagination. Does knowledge bring about imagination or does imagination, which only mankind possesses, drive you towards knowledge, towards self-improvement, towards a better life? I believe that without imagination mankind would become stagnant and without knowledge imagination will die. Even though it sounds like self-contradiction, I strongly urge to look inside my posts and find that I see two worlds, two lives – this one and the one that comes afterwards. There are things that strengthen this one that comes from the desire to enter that one.
